newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT - Dollar revival or dead-cat bounce?.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - Dollar revival or dead-cat bounce?.

text.p: The dollar moved sharply higher on Thursday on technical forces having little to do with its own outlook, technical analysts said on Thursday.
Investors dumped Swiss francs and yen, giving the dollar incidental support and lifting it from its recent range bottoms, chartists said.
But the greenback failed to convince analysts that it has the momentum to revisit recent multiyear highs without fresh corrective losses.
"Dollar/Swiss was a leader, but it still looks pretty ugly," said Scott Siller at MCM CurrencyWatch.
"Dollar/Swiss lost support at 1.4525 before we got a surprising rebound, but I still think it's a sale under 1.4685," the MCM technical analyst added.

Dollar/mark followed a similar course, aided by Bundesbank council member Helmut Hesse's reported remarks that he saw no reason to intervene to cap dollar/mark. The greenback quickly rebounded from an early slump below support at 1.6920 marks.

"Many people got caught short after the Hesse comment. It chased a lot of shorts out of the market, but that's not to say the dollar isn't toppish," said Keith Raphael, president of Crosscurrents Investment Advisory.

Chartists expect the dollar to fall well short of last week's three-year high at 1.7210 marks, yielding a test of medium-term support near 1.6800-25. Dollar/Swiss could target support near 1.44, techs said.
Dollar/yen continues to draw residual support from the firming mark/yen cross, which for now seems content to crawl towards 72.50-55 resistance, technicians said.
Coming sessions could bring a test of 72.90 and 73.30, Fibonacci retracements of the decline from February's high of 75.29 to last week's low at 70.50.
"There's still a well-defined mark/yen bull channel," Siller said.
But like dollar/mark, dollar/yen is expected to hold below its February five-year high at 124.82.
Elsewhere, the British pound sits precariously on a weekly support at $1.5970, which protects it from a two-percent move to the downside, said Raphael.
"Sterling made only a very weak rally toward 2.73 marks today and it's vulnerable to a dip toward $1.5650 next week," he added.
